mil3.7.14:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is it possible to cut through the subtlest of all things?”

mil3.7.14:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, it is possible to cut through the subtlest of all things.”

mil3.7.14:1.4.eng: “Then what, venerable sir, is the subtlest of all things?”

mil3.7.14:1.5.pli: “Dhammo kho, mahārāja, sabbasukhumo, na kho, mahārāja, dhammā sabbe sukhumā, ‘sukhuman’ti vā ‘thūlan’ti vā dhammānametamadhivacanaṃ.
mil3.7.14:1.5.eng: “The Dhamma, your majesty, is the subtlest of all things. But not all qualities are subtle, your majesty, subtle or coarse is a designation for a quality.

mil3.7.14:1.6.pli: Yaṃ kiñci chinditabbaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ paññāya chindati, natthi dutiyaṃ paññāya chedanan”ti.
mil3.7.14:1.6.eng: Whatever is to be cut through, all that is cut through by wisdom. There is nothing else other than wisdom for cutting through.”

mil3.7.15:0.3.eng: 15. Question on the Distinction of Consciousness

mil3.7.15:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, ‘viññāṇan’ti vā ‘paññā’ti vā ‘bhūtasmiṃ jīvo’ti vā ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca, udāhu ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti?
mil3.7.15:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, when it is said ‘consciousness’ or ‘wisdom’ or ‘the life principle in a being’, are these things distinct from each other in actuality, or only in name?”

mil3.7.15:1.3.pli: “Vijānanalakkhaṇaṃ, mahārāja, viññāṇaṃ, pajānanalakkhaṇā paññā, bhūtasmiṃ jīvo nupalabbhatī”ti.
mil3.7.15:1.3.eng: “Discrimination, your majesty, is a distinguishing characteristic of consciousness, discernment is a distinguishing characteristic of wisdom, and the life principle in a being cannot be found.”

mil3.7.15:1.4.pli: “Yadi jīvo nupalabbhati, atha ko carahi cakkhunā rūpaṃ passati, sotena saddaṃ suṇāti, ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyati, jivhāya rasaṃ sāyati, kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusati, manasā dhammaṃ vijānātī”ti?
mil3.7.15:1.4.eng: “If the life principle in a being cannot be found, then how is it that one sees a form with the eyes, hears a sound with the ears, smells an odour with the nose, tastes a flavour with the tongue, touches a tangible with the body, and knows a thought with the mind?”

mil3.7.15:1.6.pli: “yadi jīvo cakkhunā rūpaṃ passati …pe… manasā dhammaṃ vijānāti, so jīvo cakkhudvāresu uppāṭitesu mahantena ākāsena bahimukho suṭṭhutaraṃ rūpaṃ passeyya, sotesu uppāṭitesu, ghāne uppāṭite, jivhāya uppāṭitāya, kāye uppāṭite mahantena ākāsena suṭṭhutaraṃ saddaṃ suṇeyya, gandhaṃ ghāyeyya, rasaṃ sāyeyya, phoṭṭhabbaṃ phuseyyā”ti?
mil3.7.15:1.6.eng: “If the life principle sees form with the eyes, … and knows thought with the mind, then when the doors of the eyes are destroyed would not the life principle see form more clearly out there before it in the great space? When the ears, the nose, the tongue and the body are all destroyed, would it not hear a sound, smell an odour, taste a flavour, touch a tangible more clearly in the great space?”

mil3.7.15:1.8.eng: “Well then, your majesty, the life principle in a being cannot be found.”

mil3.7.15:3.1.eng: Question on the Distinction of Consciousness fifteenth

mil3.7.16:0.3.eng: 16. The Question on the Difficulty of Distinguishing Formless Dhammas

mil3.7.16:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, dukkaraṃ nu kho bhagavatā katan”ti?
mil3.7.16:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, did the Blessed One accomplish something difficult?”

mil3.7.16:1.4.eng: “The Blessed One accomplished something difficult, your majesty.”

mil3.7.16:1.5.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhante nāgasena, bhagavatā dukkaraṃ katan”ti.
mil3.7.16:1.5.eng: “But what difficult thing, Venerable Nāgasena, did the Blessed One accomplish?”

mil3.7.16:1.6.pli: “Dukkaraṃ, mahārāja, bhagavatā kataṃ imesaṃ arūpīnaṃ cittacetasikānaṃ dhammānaṃ ekārammaṇe vattamānānaṃ vavatthānaṃ akkhātaṃ ‘ayaṃ phasso, ayaṃ vedanā, ayaṃ saññā, ayaṃ cetanā, idaṃ cittan’”ti.
mil3.7.16:1.6.eng: “The Blessed One accomplished something difficult, your majesty, in that he explained the distinction of these formless mental dhammas that occur with a single object, declaring: ‘This is contact, this is feeling, this is perception, this is volition, this is consciousness.’”

mil3.7.16:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso nāvāya mahāsamuddaṃ ajjhogāhetvā hatthapuṭena udakaṃ gahetvā jivhāya sāyitvā jāneyya nu kho, mahārāja, so puriso ‘idaṃ gaṅgāya udakaṃ, idaṃ yamunāya udakaṃ, idaṃ aciravatiyā udakaṃ, idaṃ sarabhuyā udakaṃ, idaṃ mahiyā udakan’”ti?
mil3.7.16:2.2.eng: “Suppose, your majesty, some man were to go out onto the great ocean in a boat, take up water in the hollow of his hand, taste it with his tongue—would that man be able to know: ‘This is water from the Ganges, this is water from the Yamunā, this is water from the Aciravatī, this is water from the Sarabhū, this is water from the Mahī’?”

mil3.7.16:2.3.eng: “It would be difficult to know, venerable sir.”

mil3.7.16:2.4.pli: “Ito dukkarataraṃ kho, mahārāja, bhagavatā kataṃ imesaṃ arūpīnaṃ cittacetasikānaṃ dhammānaṃ ekārammaṇe vattamānānaṃ vavatthānaṃ akkhātaṃ ‘ayaṃ phasso, ayaṃ vedanā, ayaṃ saññā, ayaṃ cetanā, idaṃ cittan’”ti.
mil3.7.16:2.4.eng: “More difficult than that, your majesty, is what the Blessed One accomplished in explaining the distinction of these formless phenomena that occur with a single object, declaring: ‘This is contact, this is feeling, this is perception, this is volition, this is consciousness.’”

mil3.7.16:2.5.eng: “Very good, venerable sir,” said the king in approval.

mil3.7.16:3.1.eng: The Question on the Difficulty of Distinguishing Formless Dhammas sixteenth

mil3.7.16:4.1.eng: Analysis of Formless Dhammas Chapter seventh

mil3.7.2:0.3.eng: 2. Question on Obtaining Mindfulness on a Quality of the Buddha

mil3.7.2:1.3.pli: ‘yo vassasataṃ akusalaṃ kareyya, maraṇakāle ca ekaṃ buddhaguṇaṃ satiṃ paṭilabheyya, so devesu uppajjeyyā’ti etaṃ na saddahāmi, evañca pana vadetha ‘ekena pāṇātipātena niraye uppajjeyyā’ti etampi na saddahāmī”ti.
mil3.7.2:1.3.eng: ‘One could do evil for a hundred years, but at the time of death might obtain a single mindful moment on a quality of the Buddha, and thus arise in the realm of the devas,’ I don’t believe this. And then you said, ‘One might arise in a hell realm by killing one person,’ this too I don’t believe.”

mil3.7.2:2.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, khuddakopi pāsāṇo vinā nāvāya udake uppilaveyyā”ti.
mil3.7.2:2.1.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, could even a small stone float on the water without a boat?”

mil3.7.2:2.3.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, vāhasatampi pāsāṇānaṃ nāvāya āropitaṃ udake uppilaveyyā”ti?
mil3.7.2:2.3.eng: “But, your majesty, could even a load of a hundred stones loaded onto a boat float on the water?”

mil3.7.2:2.5.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, nāvā, evaṃ kusalāni kammāni daṭṭhabbānī”ti.
mil3.7.2:2.5.eng: “Your majesty, skilled deeds should be considered as like a boat.”

mil3.7.2:4.1.eng: Question on Obtaining Mindfulness on a Quality of the Buddha second

mil3.7.3:0.3.eng: 3. Question on Striving for the Abandonment of Suffering

mil3.7.3:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, kiṃ tumhe atītassa dukkhassa pahānāya vāyamathā”ti?
mil3.7.3:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, are you striving for the abandonment of past suffering?”

mil3.7.3:1.4.pli: “Kiṃ pana, bhante, anāgatassa dukkhassa pahānāya vāyamathā”ti?
mil3.7.3:1.4.eng: “Then, venerable sir, are you striving for the abandonment of future suffering?”

mil3.7.3:1.6.eng: “Then, venerable sir, are you striving for the abandonment of present suffering?”

mil3.7.3:1.8.pli: “Yadi tumhe na atītassa dukkhassa pahānāya vāyamatha, na anāgatassa dukkhassa pahānāya vāyamatha, na paccuppannassa dukkhassa pahānāya vāyamatha, atha kimatthāya vāyamathā”ti.
mil3.7.3:1.8.eng: “If you are not striving for the abandonment of past suffering, nor for the abandonment of future suffering, nor for the abandonment of present suffering, then what are you striving for?”

mil3.7.3:1.10.pli: “‘kinti, mahārāja, idañca dukkhaṃ nirujjheyya, aññañca dukkhaṃ nuppajjeyyā’ti etadatthāya vāyamāmā”ti.
mil3.7.3:1.10.eng: “Your majesty, I am striving so that this suffering would cease and that no other suffering would arise.”

mil3.7.3:2.1.pli: “Atthi pana te, bhante nāgasena, anāgataṃ dukkhan”ti?
mil3.7.3:2.1.eng: “Is there now, Venerable Nāgasena, future suffering for you?”

mil3.7.3:2.3.pli: “Tumhe kho, bhante nāgasena, atipaṇḍitā, ye tumhe asantānaṃ anāgatānaṃ dukkhānaṃ pahānāya vāyamathā”ti?
mil3.7.3:2.3.eng: “Indeed, Venerable Nāgasena, you are very wise that you strive for abandoning future suffering that is not existing.”

mil3.7.3:2.4.pli: “Atthi pana te, mahārāja, keci paṭirājāno paccatthikā paccāmittā paccupaṭṭhitā hontī”ti?
mil3.7.3:2.4.eng: “Are there, your majesty, any opposing kings, that are adversaries, that have risen up against you?”

mil3.7.3:2.6.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, tadā tumhe parikhaṃ khaṇāpeyyātha, pākāraṃ cināpeyyātha gopuraṃ kārāpeyyātha, aṭṭālakaṃ kārāpeyyātha, dhaññaṃ atiharāpeyyāthā”ti?
mil3.7.3:2.6.eng: “Is it then, your majesty, that you had a moat dug, a rampart put up, and a gateway and watchtower constructed?”

mil3.7.3:2.7.pli: “Na hi, bhante, paṭikacceva taṃ paṭiyattaṃ hotī”ti.
mil3.7.3:2.7.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, these were prepared previously.”

mil3.7.3:2.8.pli: “Kiṃ tumhe, mahārāja, tadā hatthismiṃ sikkheyyātha, assasmiṃ sikkheyyātha, rathasmiṃ sikkheyyātha, dhanusmiṃ sikkheyyātha, tharusmiṃ sikkheyyāthā”ti?
mil3.7.3:2.8.eng: “Is it then, your majesty, that you would train in elephant warfare, in horse warfare, in chariot warfare, in archery, and in swordsmanship?”

mil3.7.3:2.9.pli: “Na hi, bhante, paṭikacceva taṃ sikkhitaṃ hotī”ti.
mil3.7.3:2.9.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, I had trained in these previously.”

mil3.7.3:2.11.eng: “In order to prevent future perils, venerable sir.”

mil3.7.3:2.12.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, atthi anāgataṃ bhayan”ti?
mil3.7.3:2.12.eng: “Is there a future peril now, your majesty?”

mil3.7.3:2.14.pli: “Tumhe ca kho, mahārāja, atipaṇḍitā, ye tumhe asantānaṃ anāgatānaṃ bhayānaṃ paṭibāhanatthāya paṭiyādethā”ti.
mil3.7.3:2.14.eng: “Indeed, your majesty, you are very wise that you would prepare for the prevention of a future peril that is not existing.”

mil3.7.3:3.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yadā tvaṃ pipāsito bhaveyyāsi, tadā tvaṃ udapānaṃ khaṇāpeyyāsi, pokkharaṇiṃ khaṇāpeyyāsi, taḷākaṃ khaṇāpeyyāsi ‘pānīyaṃ pivissāmī’”ti?
mil3.7.3:3.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, when you might become thirsty is it then that you would have a well, a pond, or a reservoir dug, thinking, ‘I will drink water’?”

mil3.7.3:3.3.pli: “Na hi, bhante, paṭikacceva taṃ paṭiyattaṃ hotī”ti.
mil3.7.3:3.3.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, this has been arranged for previously.”

mil3.7.3:3.5.eng: “It has been arranged, venerable sir, in order to prevent future thirst.”

mil3.7.3:3.6.eng: “Is there a future thirst now, your majesty?”

mil3.7.3:3.8.pli: “Tumhe kho, mahārāja, atipaṇḍitā, ye tumhe asantānaṃ anāgatānaṃ pipāsānaṃ paṭibāhanatthāya taṃ paṭiyādethā”ti.
mil3.7.3:3.8.eng: “Indeed, your majesty, you are very wise that you would prepare for the prevention of a future thirst that is not existing.”

mil3.7.3:4.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yadā tvaṃ bubhukkhito bhaveyyāsi, tadā tvaṃ khettaṃ kasāpeyyāsi, sāliṃ vapāpeyyāsi ‘bhattaṃ bhuñjissāmī’”ti?
mil3.7.3:4.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, when you might become hungry is it then that you would have a field ploughed, and rice sowed, thinking, ‘I will eat food’?”

mil3.7.3:4.3.pli: “Na hi, bhante, paṭikacceva taṃ paṭiyattaṃ hotī”ti.
mil3.7.3:4.3.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, this has been arranged for previously.”

mil3.7.3:4.5.eng: “In order, venerable sir, to prevent future hunger.”

mil3.7.3:4.6.eng: “Is there a future hunger now, your majesty?”

mil3.7.3:4.8.pli: “Tumhe kho, mahārāja, atipaṇḍitā, ye tumhe asantānaṃ anāgatānaṃ bubhukkhānaṃ paṭibāhanatthāya paṭiyādethā”ti.
mil3.7.3:4.8.eng: “Indeed, your majesty, you are very wise that you would prepare for the prevention of a future hunger that is not existing.”

mil3.7.3:6.1.eng: Question on Striving for the Abandonment of Suffering third

mil3.7.4:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, how far away is it from here to the Brahma world?”

mil3.7.4:1.3.pli: “Dūro kho, mahārāja, ito brahmaloko kūṭāgāramattā silā tamhā patitā ahorattena aṭṭhacattālīsayojanasahassāni bhassamānā catūhi māsehi pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhaheyyā”ti.
mil3.7.4:1.3.eng: “So far, your majesty, that if a rock the size of a peaked-roof building had fallen from there, and falling at the speed of eighty-four thousand yojanas per day, it would take four months to land on the earth.”

mil3.7.4:2.2.pli: ‘seyyathāpi balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya;
mil3.7.4:2.2.eng: ‘Just as a strong man might stretch out his bent arm or bend his stretched arm,

mil3.7.4:2.3.pli: evameva iddhimā bhikkhu cetovasippatto jambudīpe antarahito brahmaloke pātubhaveyyā’ti etaṃ vacanaṃ na saddahāmi, evaṃ atisīghaṃ tāva bahūni yojanasatāni gacchissatī”ti.
mil3.7.4:2.3.eng: in the same way a bhikkhu with psychic powers who has attained mastery over his mind could disappear from Jambudīpa and appear in the Brahma world.’ This I do not believe that one might go so quickly over so many hundreds of yojanas.”

mil3.7.4:3.2.eng: “Where then, your majesty, is the place of your birth?”

mil3.7.4:3.3.pli: “Atthi, bhante, alasando nāma dīpo, tatthāhaṃ jāto”ti.
mil3.7.4:3.3.eng: “There is, venerable sir, an island called Alasanda, there I was born.”

mil3.7.4:3.4.eng: “How far away, your majesty, is Alasanda from here?”

mil3.7.4:3.6.pli: “Abhijānāsi nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, tattha kiñcideva karaṇīyaṃ karitvā saritā”ti?
mil3.7.4:3.6.eng: “Do you not know, your majesty, of some business that you have completed there and now remember?”

mil3.7.4:3.8.pli: “Lahuṃ kho tvaṃ, mahārāja, gatosi dvimattāni yojanasatānī”ti.
mil3.7.4:3.8.eng: “Indeed, so quickly you have gone about two hundred yojanas, your majesty!”

mil3.7.4:5.1.eng: Question on the Brahma World fourth

mil3.7.5:0.3.eng: 5. Question on Arising in Two Places Taking the Same Time

mil3.7.5:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yo idha kālaṅkato brahmaloke uppajjeyya, yo ca idha kālaṅkato kasmīre uppajjeyya, ko cirataraṃ ko sīghataran”ti?
mil3.7.5:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, for one who having passed away is reborn in the Brahma world, and for one who having passed away is reborn in Kashmir, which one takes the longer time, and which the shorter?”

mil3.7.5:2.2.eng: “Where then, your majesty, is your town of birth?”

mil3.7.5:2.3.eng: “There is a place called Kalasigāma, there I was born.”

mil3.7.5:2.4.eng: “How far away, your majesty, is Kalasigāma from here?”

mil3.7.5:2.6.eng: “How far away, your majesty, is Kashmir from here?”

mil3.7.5:2.8.eng: “Go on then, your majesty, think about Kalasigāma.”

mil3.7.5:2.9.eng: “I have thought about it, venerable sir.”

mil3.7.5:2.10.eng: “Go on then, your majesty, think about Kashmir.”

mil3.7.5:2.11.eng: “I have thought about it, venerable sir.”

mil3.7.5:2.12.pli: “Katamaṃ nu kho, mahārāja, cirena cintitaṃ, katamaṃ sīghataran”ti?
mil3.7.5:2.12.eng: “Which thinking took a long time, your majesty, and which a short time?”

mil3.7.5:2.14.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yo idha kālaṅkato brahmaloke uppajjeyya, yo ca idha kālaṅkato kasmīre uppajjeyya, samakaṃyeva uppajjantī”ti.
mil3.7.5:2.14.eng: “Just so, your majesty, for one who having passed away is reborn in the Brahma world, and for one who having passed away is reborn in Kashmir, they happen in the same time.”

mil3.7.5:3.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, dve sakuṇā ākāsena gaccheyyuṃ, tesu eko ucce rukkhe nisīdeyya, eko nīce rukkhe nisīdeyya, tesaṃ samakaṃ patiṭṭhitānaṃ katamassa chāyā paṭhamataraṃ pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhaheyya, katamassa chāyā cirena pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhaheyyā”ti?
mil3.7.5:3.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, if two birds fly in the sky and one sits in a high tree, and the other in a low tree, if these happen at the same time, the shadow of which one would settle on the ground first, and which one later?”

mil3.7.5:3.4.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yo idha kālaṅkato brahmaloke uppajjeyya, yo ca idha kālaṅkato kasmīre uppajjeyya, samakaṃyeva uppajjantī”ti.
mil3.7.5:3.4.eng: “Just so, your majesty, for one who having passed away is reborn in the Brahma world, and for one who having passed away is reborn in Kashmir, they happen in the same time.”

mil3.7.5:5.1.eng: Question on Arising in Two Places Taking the Same Time fifth

mil3.7.6:0.3.eng: 6. Question on the Factors for Awakening

mil3.7.6:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, how many factors for awakening are there?”

mil3.7.6:1.3.eng: “There are seven factors for awakening, your majesty.”

mil3.7.6:1.4.eng: “By how many of these seven factors for awakening, venerable sir, does one awaken?”

mil3.7.6:1.5.eng: “One awakens by one of these, your majesty, the awakening factor of discrimination of states.”

mil3.7.6:1.6.pli: “Atha kissa nu kho, bhante, vuccanti ‘satta bojjhaṅgā’”ti?
mil3.7.6:1.6.eng: “Then, venerable sir, why is it that one speaks of seven factors?”

mil3.7.6:1.7.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, asi kosiyā pakkhitto aggahito hatthena ussahati chejjaṃ chinditun”ti.
mil3.7.6:1.7.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, if a sword is placed in its sheath and not grasped in the hand is it able to cut what is to be cut?”

mil3.7.6:1.9.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgena vinā chahi bojjhaṅgehi na bujjhatī”ti.
mil3.7.6:1.9.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, without the investigation of states awakening factor, one cannot awaken by the other six factors.”

mil3.7.6:3.1.eng: Question on the Factors for Awakening sixth

mil3.7.7:0.3.eng: 7. Question on the Increase or Decrease of Merit and Demerit

mil3.7.7:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, kataraṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ puññaṃ vā apuññaṃ vā”ti?
mil3.7.7:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, which of the two is greater, merit or demerit?”

mil3.7.7:1.3.eng: “Merit is greater, your majesty, demerit is small.”

mil3.7.7:1.5.pli: “Apuññaṃ kho, mahārāja, karonto vippaṭisārī hoti ‘pāpakammaṃ mayā katan’ti, tena pāpaṃ na vaḍḍhati.
mil3.7.7:1.5.eng: “For one doing demerit, your majesty, there is the regret, ‘I have committed an evil deed’, and therefore demerit does not increase.

mil3.7.7:1.6.pli: Puññaṃ kho, mahārāja, karonto avippaṭisārī hoti, avippaṭisārino pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati, samāhito yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, tena kāraṇena puññaṃ vaḍḍhati.
mil3.7.7:1.6.eng: But for one doing merit, your majesty, there is no regret; and for one without regret gladness arises; for one who is glad joy arises; for one with a joyous mind the body calms down; one with a calmed body experiences happiness; the mind of one who is happy becomes concentrated; and one who is concentrated knows things as they really are. For this reason, merit increases.

mil3.7.7:1.7.pli: Puriso kho, mahārāja, chinnahatthapādo bhagavato ekaṃ uppalahatthaṃ datvā ekanavutikappāni vinipātaṃ na gacchissati.
mil3.7.7:1.7.eng: Even if a man with his hands and feet cut off gives just a handful of lotuses to the Blessed One, he will not go to a hell realm for ninety-one eons.

mil3.7.7:1.8.pli: Imināpi, mahārāja, kāraṇena bhaṇāmi ‘puññaṃ bahutaraṃ, apuññaṃ thokan’”ti.
mil3.7.7:1.8.eng: For this reason, your majesty, merit is greater and demerit is small.”

mil3.7.7:3.1.eng: Question on the Increase or Decrease of Merit and Demerit seventh

mil3.7.8:0.3.eng: 8. Question on Doing Evil Knowingly or Unknowingly

mil3.7.8:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, yo jānanto pāpakammaṃ karoti, yo ajānanto pāpakammaṃ karoti, kassa bahutaraṃ apuññan”ti?
mil3.7.8:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, for whom is the greater demerit, one who knowingly does evil, or one who does evil unknowingly?”

mil3.7.8:1.3.pli: Thero āha “yo kho, mahārāja, ajānanto pāpakammaṃ karoti, tassa bahutaraṃ apuññan”ti.
mil3.7.8:1.3.eng: The elder replied: “Indeed, great king, for him who does evil unknowingly is the greater demerit.”

mil3.7.8:1.4.pli: “Tena hi, bhante nāgasena, yo amhākaṃ rājaputto vā rājamahāmatto vā ajānanto pāpakammaṃ karoti, taṃ mayaṃ diguṇaṃ daṇḍemā”ti?
mil3.7.8:1.4.eng: “In that case, Venerable Nāgasena, that one who is our prince or king’s chief minister who unknowingly does evil, we should doubly punish him?”

mil3.7.8:1.5.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, tattaṃ ayoguḷaṃ ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ eko jānanto gaṇheyya, eko ajānanto gaṇheyya, katamo balavataraṃ ḍayheyyā”ti.
mil3.7.8:1.5.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, who would get burned more, one who knowingly picks up a hot iron ball, ablaze and glowing, or one who unknowingly picks it up?”

mil3.7.8:1.6.pli: “Yo kho, bhante, ajānanto gaṇheyya, so balavataraṃ ḍayheyyā”ti.
mil3.7.8:1.6.eng: “Indeed, venerable sir, he who unknowingly picks it up would get burned more.”

mil3.7.8:1.7.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yo ajānanto pāpakammaṃ karoti, tassa bahutaraṃ apuññan”ti.
mil3.7.8:1.7.eng: “Indeed, your majesty, in the same way the greater demerit is for him who does evil unknowingly.”

mil3.7.8:3.1.eng: Question on Doing Evil Knowingly or Unknowingly eighth

mil3.7.9:0.3.eng: 9. Question on Travelling to Uttarakuru and Other Places

mil3.7.9:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, atthi koci, yo iminā sarīrena uttarakuruṃ vā gaccheyya, brahmalokaṃ vā, aññaṃ vā pana dīpan”ti?
mil3.7.9:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is there anybody who, with this mortal body, could go to Uttarakuru or to the Brahma world or to another continent?”

mil3.7.9:1.3.pli: “Atthi, mahārāja, yo iminā cātummahābhūtikena kāyena uttarakuruṃ vā gaccheyya, brahmalokaṃ vā, aññaṃ vā pana dīpan”ti.
mil3.7.9:1.3.eng: “There is, your majesty, someone who could, with this body composed of the four great elements, go to Uttarakuru or to the Brahma world or to another continent.”

mil3.7.9:2.1.pli: “Kathaṃ, bhante nāgasena, iminā cātummahābhūtikena kāyena uttarakuruṃ vā gaccheyya, brahmalokaṃ vā, aññaṃ vā pana dīpan”ti?
mil3.7.9:2.1.eng: “How, Venerable Nāgasena, could one, with this body composed of the four great elements, go to Uttarakuru or to the Brahma world or to another continent?”

mil3.7.9:2.2.pli: “Abhijānāsi nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, imissā pathaviyā vidatthiṃ vā ratanaṃ vā laṅghitā”ti?
mil3.7.9:2.2.eng: “Your majesty, have you had the direct experience of jumping a hand span or a cubit on this earth?”

mil3.7.9:2.3.pli: “Āma, bhante, abhijānāmi ‘ahaṃ, bhante nāgasena, aṭṭhapi rataniyo laṅghemī’”ti.
mil3.7.9:2.3.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, I have had that direct experience, in fact I jump even eight cubits.”

mil3.7.9:2.4.eng: “How, your majesty, do you jump even eight cubits?”

mil3.7.9:2.5.pli: “Ahañhi, bhante, cittaṃ uppādemi ‘ettha nipatissāmī’ti saha cittuppādena kāyo me lahuko hotī”ti.
mil3.7.9:2.5.eng: “Venerable sir, I generate the thought ‘I will land here,’ and with that thought my body is buoyant.”

mil3.7.9:2.6.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, iddhimā bhikkhu cetovasippatto kāyaṃ citte samāropetvā cittavasena vehāsaṃ gacchatī”ti.
mil3.7.9:2.6.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, a bhikkhu with psychic power and who has achieved mastery over his own mind, having entrusted his body to his mind, travels in the sky by means of this mind mastery.”

mil3.7.9:4.1.eng: Question on Travelling to Uttarakuru and Other Places ninth

mil3.8:0.2.eng: 8. The Asking and Answering of Milinda’s Questions

mil3.8:1.2.eng: “Do you know, your majesty, what time it is now?”

mil3.8:1.3.pli: “Āma, bhante, jānāmi ‘sampati paṭhamo yāmo atikkanto, majjhimo yāmo pavattati, ukkā padīpīyanti, cattāri paṭākāni āṇattāni gamissanti bhaṇḍato rājadeyyānī’”ti.
mil3.8:1.3.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, I know. ‘The first watch of the night has passed, the middle watch is proceeding, the torches are lit, and the four banners have been commanded to go from the treasury bearing royal gifts.’”

mil3.8:2.1.eng: The Bactrian Greeks said this: “You are clever, your majesty, the elder is wise.”

mil3.8:2.2.pli: “Āma, bhaṇe, paṇḍito thero, ediso ācariyo bhaveyya mādiso ca antevāsī, nacirasseva paṇḍito dhammaṃ ājāneyyā”ti.
mil3.8:2.2.eng: “Yes, friends, the elder is wise. If there were a teacher such as he and a pupil such as myself, before long a wise person would understand the Dhamma.”

mil3.8:2.3.pli: Tassa pañhaveyyākaraṇena tuṭṭho rājā theraṃ nāgasenaṃ satasahassagghanakena kambalena acchādetvā “bhante nāgasena, ajjatagge te aṭṭhasataṃ bhattaṃ paññapemi, yaṃ kiñci antepure kappiyaṃ, tena ca pavāremī”ti—āha.
mil3.8:2.3.eng: Pleased with his answering of questions, the king covered the elder Nāgasena with a blanket worth a hundred thousand (kahāpaṇas) saying: “Venerable Nāgasena, from today I establish for you a meal for eight hundred, and I invite you with whatever is allowable in the inner palace.”

mil3.8:2.5.pli: “Jānāmi, bhante nāgasena, jīvasi, api ca attānañca rakkha, mamañca rakkhāhī”ti.
mil3.8:2.5.eng: “I know, Venerable Nāgasena, that you are living, but still protect yourself and protect me too.”

mil3.8:2.6.pli: “Kathaṃ attānaṃ rakkhasi, ‘nāgaseno milindaṃ rājānaṃ pasādeti, na ca kiñci alabhī’ti parāpavādo āgaccheyyāti, evaṃ attānaṃ rakkha.
mil3.8:2.6.eng: “How do you protect yourself? ‘Nāgasena pleased King Milinda but received nothing’—lest such reproach should come, thus protect yourself.

mil3.8:2.7.pli: Kathaṃ mamaṃ rakkhasi, ‘milindo rājā pasanno pasannākāraṃ na karotī’ti parāpavādo āgaccheyyāti, evaṃ mamaṃ rakkhāhī”ti.
mil3.8:2.7.eng: How should you protect me? ‘King Milinda was pleased but showed no sign of his pleasure’—lest such reproach should come, thus protect me.”

mil3.8:2.9.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhante, sīho migarājā suvaṇṇapañjare pakkhittopi bahimukhoyeva hoti;
mil3.8:2.9.eng: “Just as, venerable sir, a lion, the king of beasts, even when placed in a golden cage, remains outward-facing;

mil3.8:2.10.pli: evameva kho ahaṃ, bhante, kiñcāpi agāraṃ ajjhāvasāmi bahimukho yeva pana acchāmi.
mil3.8:2.10.eng: even so, venerable sir, though I dwell in a house, I remain outward-facing.

mil3.8:2.11.pli: Sace ahaṃ, bhante, agārasmā anāgāriyaṃ pabbajeyyaṃ, na ciraṃ jīveyyaṃ, bahū me paccatthikā”ti.
mil3.8:2.11.eng: If I, venerable sir, were to go forth from the household life into homelessness, I would not live long, so many are my enemies.”

mil3.8:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgaseno milindassa rañño pañhaṃ visajjetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā saṅghārāmaṃ agamāsi.
mil3.8:3.1.eng: Then the Venerable Nāgasena, having answered King Milinda’s question, rose from his seat and went to the monastery.

mil3.8:3.2.pli: Acirapakkante ca āyasmante nāgasene milindassa rañño etadahosi—
mil3.8:3.2.eng: Not long after the Venerable Nāgasena had departed, this occurred to King Milinda:

mil3.8:3.3.pli: “kiṃ mayā pucchitaṃ, kiṃ bhadantena nāgasenena visajjitan”ti?
mil3.8:3.3.eng: “What did I ask? What did the Venerable Nāgasena answer?”

mil3.8:3.4.eng: Then this occurred to King Milinda:

mil3.8:3.5.pli: “sabbaṃ mayā supucchitaṃ, sabbaṃ bhadantena nāgasenena suvisajjitan”ti.
mil3.8:3.5.eng: “Everything was well asked by me, everything was well answered by the Venerable Nāgasena.”

mil3.8:3.6.eng: And to the Venerable Nāgasena, having reached the monastery, this occurred:

mil3.8:3.7.pli: “kiṃ milindena raññā pucchitaṃ, kiṃ mayā visajjitan”ti.
mil3.8:3.7.eng: “What did King Milinda ask? What did I answer?”

mil3.8:3.8.eng: Then this occurred to the Venerable Nāgasena:

mil3.8:3.9.pli: “sabbaṃ milindena raññā supucchitaṃ, sabbaṃ mayā suvisajjitan”ti.
mil3.8:3.9.eng: “Everything was well asked by King Milinda, everything was well answered by me.”

mil3.8:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nāgaseno tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena milindassa rañño nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mil3.8:4.1.eng: Then the Venerable Nāgasena, when that night had passed, in the morning having dressed and taking his bowl and robe, approached King Milinda’s dwelling, and then sat down on the seat prepared.

mil3.8:4.2.pli: Atha kho milindo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi, ekamantaṃ nisinno kho milindo rājā āyasmantaṃ nāgasenaṃ etadavoca—
mil3.8:4.2.eng: Then King Milinda, paid respects to the Venerable Nāgasena, and sat down to one side. Sitting to one side, King Milinda said this to the Venerable Nāgasena:

mil3.8:5.1.pli: “Mā kho bhadantassa evaṃ ahosi ‘nāgaseno mayā pañhaṃ pucchito’ti teneva somanassena taṃ rattāvasesaṃ vītināmesīti na te evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mil3.8:5.1.eng: “May the venerable one not think thus: ‘Nāgasena was asked a question by me,’ and with that very joy pass the rest of that night—it should not be seen thus by you.

mil3.8:5.2.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, taṃ rattāvasesaṃ etadahosi—
mil3.8:5.2.eng: For me, venerable sir, during the rest of that night, this occurred:

mil3.8:5.3.pli: ‘kiṃ mayā pucchitaṃ, kiṃ bhadantena visajjitan’ti, ‘sabbaṃ mayā supucchitaṃ, sabbaṃ bhadantena suvisajjitan’”ti.
mil3.8:5.3.eng: ‘What did I ask? What was answered by the venerable one?’—‘Everything was well asked by me, everything was well answered by the venerable one.’”

mil3.8:6.2.pli: “mā kho mahārājassa evaṃ ahosi ‘milindassa rañño mayā pañho visajjito’ti teneva somanassena taṃ rattāvasesaṃ vītināmesīti na te evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mil3.8:6.2.eng: “May it not occur to your majesty thus: ‘King Milinda’s question was answered by me,’ and with that very joy pass the rest of that night—it should not be seen thus by you.

mil3.8:6.3.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, mahārāja, taṃ rattāvasesaṃ etadahosi—
mil3.8:6.3.eng: For me, your majesty, during the rest of that night, this occurred:

mil3.8:6.4.pli: ‘kiṃ milindena raññā pucchitaṃ, kiṃ mayā visajjitan’ti, ‘sabbaṃ milindena raññā supucchitaṃ, sabbaṃ mayā suvisajjitan’”ti itiha te mahānāgā aññamaññassa subhāsitaṃ samanumodiṃsūti.
mil3.8:6.4.eng: ‘What was asked by King Milinda? What did I answer?’—‘Everything was well asked by King Milinda, everything was well answered by me.’” Thus these great beings mutually rejoiced in each other’s well-spoken words.

mil3.8:7.1.eng: The Asking and Answering of Milinda’s Questions completed
